(1 comment)
Patch Set 25: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 0af78d5a61687d999d7ec68b003137db1201b225
Which tests?
sorry, I mean the tests in test/redfish-core/include/redfish_aggregator_test.cpp
Done

This commit also implements Links, which as-written the code looks like it won't function correctly for.  Can you please test that before you submit your next patch, or omit it it if you don't plan on testing it?
I will omit "Link" for now
Done
+1 to what Ed said.
At some point, I'd also like to see a more cohesive list of headers the spec returns, so we can port them through the aggregator.
Curious. Why item["temp"] and not just item?
Casting to string shouldn't be needed here.  nlohmann::json supports string_view.
+1.  This code is quite confusing to me, we appear to load the value into a nlohmann::json object, just to pull it back out again?  Why don't we just operate on a copy of the location variable?
Done. My mistake, I remember `item` did not work but it does.
Done. You're right, it's not needed. Thanks for catching this.

oh, I see.  addPrefixToItem takes a nlohmann::json object.  I think the answer is we need to break down addPrefixToItem into two methods, one that takes a string, and one that takes a nlohmann::object, which calls the string version.  That way, we're not constructing arbitrary objects just for the sake of it.

Yes, I created the item object for addPrefixToItem purpose. It's one extra line for the item creation, if you think we should split addPrefixToItem into 2 methods, I can do that too. What do you suggest?
Done

It's not about "one extra line" it's about understanding the data structures, being efficient, and making methods that do what they intend without extra steps, because those steps can fail, or do unexpected things in the future.

Looks like what you have now should be fine.
Per the developing guide, this cast throws if item["temp"] isn't of type string.  If this is still used in the later version, use get_ptr<std::string>
Ack. I reverted back to using `item` instead.

This is going to be a metadata link, which given that we don't support $metadata correctly yet, this won't resolve properly.  Also, there's quite a bit of duplication with Location (it's basically the same transform).  We might want to deduplicate.
I see, I assumed that "Link" is similar to "Location". I will omit the "Link" changes
Done
Have you looked at the other header values the spec declares?
I added checks for other Header Values according to our conversation offline. I might have missed some, can you verify? As I recall, we don't copy any other header values to asyncResp, correct?
Done
Lets put this into a separate method "addLinksToAggregatedResponse" (or some other name that you think is better).
Done
Looking better, awaiting all the unresolved comments to be resolved
inline on all of these, not static.
Done
Do not pass by shared_ptr unless the method is taking ownership of the object.  This should be passed by Response&
Done
please use the http field enum here.
Done
Why is a string copy needed here?  This all looks used in a const context, so the string_view should be fine?
We are going to change `location` later, should we use string instead of string_view?
Done
Considering that at this point we're making a copy of the string, at some point we should just return the value.  Doesn't need done in this patch.
With that change would it be alright that when we don't perform prefix fixing we'd still end up returning the initial string?  The current approach potentially saves us from that last copy.
The location header needs modified, right?
I was modifying the resp as well, I changed it to modifying just asyncResp
I'd prefer you go ahead and make this change so you're not making multiple lookups.  You could just always call addHeaderPrefixes() and then inside of that function use Ed's example code.
Thanks for catching this. I removed addHeaderPrefixes() method, it looks a bit extra to have another function just for Location header
I'm fine with that
Nit, typo?  not sure it matters.
Done
@Carson, still looking for your input here.
It's looking pretty close to me

From https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.17.0.pdf#page=67, these are the other "Required" response headers which this function does not copy over:

* Access-Control-Allow-Origin
* Allow
* Cache-Control
* OData-Version
* www-Authenticate
* X-Auth-Token

I know OData-Version will be applied by the aggregating BMCWeb.  Will the other ones get applied as well, or do we need to forward them?

nit, I wouldn't use "Links" in the definition since you're only dealing with headers and there are other functions which add links to the response body.  IMO something like addAggregatedHeaders() is more appropriate.
Done
@Ed We discussed on Chat that we won't forward these Headers to Aggregated Resp. Is this still correct?

Access-Control-Allow-Origin, Cache-Control, OData-Version headers are set for all bmcweb Redfish responses, so no need to copy.

Allow should be copied.

www-authenticate, and x-auth-token are authentication params, and in the current model the user is logging into bmcweb, which is already authenticated with the satellite (ie we don't pass auth through) so not copying these shoudl be fine.

TL; DR, just need to get Allow in the list.
Done

This will only get called when if the "Content-Type" of the response is "application/json".  We drop any other "Content-Type".  Should this patch include support for these other header formats so that we don't drop them? https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.17.0.pdf#page=68
You're right, I moved the function outside of the if statement. Right now, it should copy over any Content-type but only when Content-type is "application/json" that we process the other headers.
Continuing in a new comment thread.

Continuation of https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/60424/comment/65186d1c_68d988e4

The new location of addAggregatedHeaders() guarantees it'll also get called.  However, this else block means we won't copy over any response that's not "application/json" and has a body.  This chunk should change to support copying over other "Content-Type"s.
So addAggregatedHeaders() will still get called and copy over "Content-Type". Any other fields we want to copy over?

I think we'd want to copy over all of the specified header fields regardless of the "Content-Type" and also copy over the body of the response in some way.

If it is an "application/json" then we need to parse the response body into a JSON, apply prefix fixing, and then copy that JSON into asyncResp.  We currently do that.

If it's not an "application/json" then just copy the body as is.  Right now we ignore the body if it's not an "application/json".  Doing this will allow us to avoid a situation where the response contains a binary payload, we copy over the headers just fine, but for the body we return an Operation Failed error.

I see, I added the change to copy the body as well. Do we want to copy the response result too? 

Also, the failing message, not sure if I should remove it now that we copy over the body and all.

Yes you want to copy over the response result as well.  That fail check should also be removed since it's now acceptable to receive a response that is not an "application/json" and does not have an empty body.
Done
Can you make this something correct to the standard please?  This isn't a valid link.
Done
You never actually copy over the "Content-Type" header
Done. I actually copied it over in the previous line
ACK, my mistake
We want these fields to be copied over regardless of the value of "Content-Type".  Right now they only get copied for "application/json"
Done
